additionalTextInformation.text:
After deprecating expertises by Friedländer and Buchner the painting was cleared for sale by Schlossmuseum Gotha. [Letter W. Schade to D. Koepplin, 2012]

In 1936 the panel was cut in the Galerie Abels, Cologne, probably to make it more sellable. The fragment with the head of St John and the bowl was returned to the Museum and the piece with Salome was sold to the Galerie P. de Boer. In 1972 the Galerie P. de Boer offered it for sale this time as a Sibylle of Saxony with a light background. A comparison of the photographs from 1937 and 1972 shows that the cracquellée on the foreheads of the women corresponds. In addition paint remnants indicate that the light background was originally dark.  

[Jacoby 2002, 197-212]

pageContext.description:
The painting shows a bust portrait of a young woman in courtly dress. She is wearing a dress with decorative slits, a neckband with a pendant and various chains. Her hair is concealed under a hairnet and she has a hat decorated with feathers on her head.
[Görres, cda 2016]

pageContext.provenance:
- 1656 listed in the inventory of  the Museum Schloss Friedenstein, Gotha
- 1936 sold by the Museum 
- Galerie Buck, Mannheim
- Galerie Abels, Cologne
- 1937 Kunsthandel P. de Boer, Amsterdam
- 09.1951 Kunsthandel Frederick Muller & Cie, Amsterdam, No. 20
[Jacoby 2002, 197-212]
- 1972 Kunsthandel P. de Boer, Amsterdam
[letter Kunsthandel P. de Boer to D. Koepplin in the D. Koepplin  Archive, 1973]
- 2012 Christie's London
[letter W. Schade to D. Koepplin, 2012]

restorationSurveys.remarks:
Bright background had been overpainted in the past with dark colours; the overpaint has been removed, reapplied and removed again:
- about 1936 with a dark background, which was removed and overpainted ("weggenommen und übermalt"); overpainting removed about 1972, the initial paint layers remained untouched ("Präparierungsuntergrundfarben") 
- despite the removal of overpaint with alcohol, the winged serpent and date remained

[information Kunsthandel P. de Boer in a letter to D. Koepplin in Archiv D. Koepplin, 1973]

pageContext.signature: Artist's insignia at the right edge: serpent and dated '1549'
